specJson.name: brightics.function.clustering$agglomerative_clustering
specJson.label: Agglomerative Clustering
specJson.description:
Agglomerative clustering is the most common type of hierarchical clustering using a bottom-up approach. Hierarchical clustering is a method of cluster analysis which seeks to build a hierarchy of clusters. Strategies for hierarchical clustering generally fall into two types; 1) Bottom-up approach: each observation starts in its own cluster, and pairs of clusters are merged as one moves up the hierarchy. 2) Top-down approach: all observations start in one cluster, and splits are performed recursively as one moves down the hierarchy.

Agglomerative clustering algorithm starts by treating each observation as a single cluster. At each step of the algorithm, the two clusters that are the most similar are combined into a new bigger cluster. This procedure is iterated until all observations are member of just one single big cluster. The result of the clustering is visualized as a dendrogram, which shows the sequence of cluster merging and the distance at which each merging took place. With output table, it shows cluster informtation joined at each iteration, height and the number of original observations in the newly formed cluster.

There are two main parameters user can choose; `Linkage Method`, `Metric`. First, `Linkage Method` determines which distance to use between sets of observation. There are serveral linkage criteria supported such as `Single`, `Average`, `Complete`, `Ward`. Second, `Metric` determines which metric to use to compute the option of `Linkage Method`. There are such options like `Euclidean`, `Minkowski`, `Cityblock`. Result of this function can be varied widely depending on the chosen `Linkage Method` and `Metric`. For more information to get some intuition about the characteristics of differenct linkage methods for hierarchical clustering, read the reference below.

Reference
+ <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hierarchical_clustering>
+ <https://www.datanovia.com/en/lessons/agglomerative-hierarchical-clustering/>

params.label: Input Columns
params.description: Columns to select as input. Only values in numeric type are possible.

params.label: Linkage
params.description:
Which linkage criterion to use. The linkage criterion determines which distance to use between sets of observation. The algorithm will merge the pairs of cluster that minimize this criterion. `Ward` is a variance-minimizing approach and use the sum of squared differences within all clusters. `Complete` uses the maximum of the distances between all observations of the two sets. `Average` uses the average of the distances between all observations of pairs of sets. `Single` uses the minimum of the distances between all observations of the two sets.
   - Available Options : `ward`, `complete`, `average`, `single`

params.label: Affinity
params.description:
Metric used to compute the linkage. Note that if linkage is `ward`, only `euclidean` is accepted.
   - Available Options : `euclidean`, `l1`, `l2`, `manhattan`, `cosine`

params.label: N Clusters
params.description:
The number of clusters to find.
   - Available Options : `True`, `False`

params.label: Compute Full Tree
params.description: Stop early the construction of the tree at n_clusters. This is useful to decrease computation time if the number of clusters is not small compared to the number of samples. This option is useful only when specifying a connectivity matrix. Note also that when varying the number of clusters and using caching, it may be advantageous to compute the full tree.

specJson.summary: This function trains an agglomerative clustering model and predicts cluster label.

md:
# Agglomerative Clustering This function trains an agglomerative clustering model and predicts cluster label. ## Description Agglomerative clustering is the most common type of hierarchical clustering using a bottom-up approach. Hierarchical clustering is a method of cluster analysis which seeks to build a hierarchy of clusters. Strategies for hierarchical clustering generally fall into two types; 1) Bottom-up approach: each observation starts in its own cluster, and pairs of clusters are merged as one moves up the hierarchy. 2) Top-down approach: all observations start in one cluster, and splits are performed recursively as one moves down the hierarchy. Agglomerative clustering algorithm starts by treating each observation as a single cluster. At each step of the algorithm, the two clusters that are the most similar are combined into a new bigger cluster. This procedure is iterated until all observations are member of just one single big cluster. The result of the clustering is visualized as a dendrogram, which shows the sequence of cluster merging and the distance at which each merging took place. With output table, it shows cluster informtation joined at each iteration, height and the number of original observations in the newly formed cluster. There are two main parameters user can choose; `Linkage Method`, `Metric`. First, `Linkage Method` determines which distance to use between sets of observation. There are serveral linkage criteria supported such as `Single`, `Average`, `Complete`, `Ward`. Second, `Metric` determines which metric to use to compute the option of `Linkage Method`. There are such options like `Euclidean`, `Minkowski`, `Cityblock`. Result of this function can be varied widely depending on the chosen `Linkage Method` and `Metric`. For more information to get some intuition about the characteristics of differenct linkage methods for hierarchical clustering, read the reference below. Reference + + ## Properties ### VA #### INPUT 1. **table***: (Table) Data in a Table. #### OUTPUT 1. **table**: (Table) A result table that contains input table and cluster label. 2. **model**: (Model) Trained Agglomerative Clustering model. #### PARAMETER 1. **Input Columns***: Columns to select as input. Only values in numeric type are possible. 2. **Prediction Column Name**: Column name for prediction. 3. **Linkage**: Which linkage criterion to use. The linkage criterion determines which distance to use between sets of observation. The algorithm will merge the pairs of cluster that minimize this criterion. `Ward` is a variance-minimizing approach and use the sum of squared differences within all clusters. `Complete` uses the maximum of the distances between all observations of the two sets. `Average` uses the average of the distances between all observations of pairs of sets. `Single` uses the minimum of the distances between all observations of the two sets. - Available Options : `ward`, `complete`, `average`, `single` 4. **Affinity**: Metric used to compute the linkage. Note that if linkage is `ward`, only `euclidean` is accepted. - Available Options : `euclidean`, `l1`, `l2`, `manhattan`, `cosine` 5. **N Clusters**: The number of clusters to find. - Available Options : `True`, `False` 6. **Compute Full Tree Auto**: Compute Full Tree Mode. 7. **Group By**: Columns to group by. ### Python #### USAGE ``` agglomerative_clustering(table, input_cols, prediction_col='prediction', linkage='ward', affinity='euclidean', n_clusters=2, compute_full_tree_auto=True, compute_full_tree=None,group_by=None) ``` #### INPUT 1. **table***: (Table) Data in a Table. #### OUTPUT 1. **table**: (Table) A result table that contains input table and cluster label. 2. **model**: (Model) Trained Agglomerative Clustering model. #### PARAMETER 1. **input_cols***: Columns to select as input. Only values in numeric type are possible. * Type: *list[str]* 2. **prediction_col**: Column name for prediction. * Type: *str* * Default / Range: prediction 3. **linkage**: Which linkage criterion to use. The linkage criterion determines which distance to use between sets of observation. The algorithm will merge the pairs of cluster that minimize this criterion. `ward` is a variance-minimizing approach and use the sum of squared differences within all clusters. `complete` uses the maximum of the distances between all observations of the two sets. `average` uses the average of the distances between all observations of pairs of sets. `single` uses the minimum of the distances between all observations of the two sets. * Type: *str* * Default / Range: ward ( ward | complete | average | single ) 4. **affinity**: Metric used to compute the linkage. Note that if linkage is `ward`, only `euclidean` is accepted. * Type: *str* * Default / Range: euclidean ( euclidean | l1 | l2 | manhattan | cosine ) 5. **n_clusters**: The number of clusters to find. * Type: *int* * Default / Range: 2 (value >= 1) 6. **compute_full_tree_auto**: Compute Full Tree Mode. * Type: *boolean* * Default / Range: true 7. **compute_full_tree**: Stop early the construction of the tree at n_clusters. This is useful to decrease computation time if the number of clusters is not small compared to the number of samples. This option is useful only when specifying a connectivity matrix. Note also that when varying the number of clusters and using caching, it may be advantageous to compute the full tree. * Type: *boolean* * Default / Range: None 8. **group_by**: Columns to group by. * Type: *list[str]* ## Example ### VA **[Related Tutorial]** **[Sample Model]**
In this tutorial workflow, sample_iris data is used in the Agglomerative Clustering function. The generated table shows cluster label for each data point. The parameter settings used in the function are shown below. ++Parameters++ 1. **Input Columns***: sepal_length, sepal_width 2. **Prediction Column Name**: prediction 3. **Linkage**: ward 4. **Affinity**: euclidean 5. **N Clusters**: 3 6. **Compute Full Tree Auto**: true 7. **Group By**: None ### Python ``` from brightics.function.clustering import agglomerative_clustering input_table = inputs[0] result = agglomerative_clustering(table=input_table, input_cols=['sepal_length', 'sepal_width'], prediction_col='prediction', linkage='ward', affinity='euclidean', n_clusters=3, compute_full_tree_auto=True, compute_full_tree=None, group_by=None) output_table = result['out_table'] output_model = result['model'] ```
In this tutorial workflow, sample_iris data is used in the Agglomerative Clustering function. The generated table shows cluster label for each data point.

guide.message: Set data options using Chart Setting Button.
